page.title: 06 Radcot Lock.
page.content: Radcot Lock was built in 1892. Motor- boats and rowing boats regularly use the lock. A private road has to be used to gain access to the lock unless one walks along the river bank from Radcot Bridge. The weir alongside the lock is a fine example of a "paddles and rymers" type. It is one of the oldest weirs on the Thames. The lock is one of the few still manually operated. Except for occasional closure for maintainance the lock can be used at any time, usually the lock keeper is in attendance between 9.00a.m. and sunset. It is only really busy during the months of June, July and August. Nearby is a steep, arched wooden foot- bridge, known as Old Man's Bridge.
